This is clear evidence of HTML injection: if a client application inserts this value into the DOM using unsafe methods (e.g., innerHTML) the onclick handler will execute arbitrary JavaScript, leading to cross-site scripting (XSS). Because this value is returned from an updateUser operation it likely represents stored data, increasing the risk of persistent XSS. Recommended mitigations: properly escape or encode HTML special characters before returning or rendering, validate/sanitize user input on the server, avoid using innerHTML or other unsafe DOM insertion APIs, and deploy a strict Content Security Policy (CSP).", "evidence": "\"name\": \"
